When I found out that Civilization IV had been out for a couple of years, I was still playing its predecessor. And if it weren't for the dozens or even hundreds of hours I've spent playing Civ3, coupled with fatigue from its limitations and dumb AI ‚Äî Civ4 could, potentially, became my favourite instalment in the whole series. Looking back, the fourth part seems to be the most polished and competent iteration of the iconic franchise. Especially if you compare the basic versions, without the paid DLC and add-ons, which the creators of the series are so like to abuse nowadays. Sid Meier's Civilization IV inherited the best features of its predecessors, polished its mechanics and made a lot of small changes and improvements to the well-established formula. Thanks to a much more user-friendly and informative interface, fancier graphics, mature stylistics (hello to cartoonish Civ6 and Revolution) and FullHD resolution support ‚Äî the project looks and plays pleasantly to this day. And the amount of starting content, old and new civilizations, as well as the presence of alternative leaders are surprising. Of the drawbacks, I could mention the traditionally inadequate behaviour of the AI (especially when playing at marathon speed on huge maps with the maximum number of opponents), as well as the "unfair" difficulty, which increases not via the "cunning" AI, but through a system of bonuses for computer opponents and penalties for the player. But both of these problems are the scourge of the entire series, which the developers have successfully ignored for over two decades. Despite its solid age, Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a great starting point for getting to know the series, especially if you're not interested in online multiplayer. Unlike the newer instalments, Sid Meier's IV is much less demanding in terms of hardware and finances but is just as addictive.

Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization IV is an addicting 4X strategy game. As a leader of one of the eighteen civilizations of the base game (that can become even more with the two expansions, Warlords and Beyond the Sword) the player is expected to explore the surrounding lands (in a potentially procedurally generated map) and expand their city borders, found new cities or conquer others to gradually become an empire and eventually win a campaign that spans from the stone age to the near future of 2050. Victory can be achieved in many ways, from being the first civilization to reach outer space, to remaining the only civilization that is left on the map. The most interesting and addicting factor of Civilization IV are the choices the player takes, each one leading their civilization‚Äôs progress in a different direction. The technology tree is interesting and varied, allowing to focus on military prowess in one game or scientific progress in another; each choice could be the better one, depending on the map, the adversaries and the success in building world wonders or founding religions. Accompanying these potentially endless games are decent graphics that are clear to understand despite the complexity of the system and an incredibly (and award winning!) soundtrack. The Warlord expansion adds six more civilizations, more leaders and unique scenarios to the main game, but is otherwise unremarkable. The Beyond the Sword expansions is a lot better, adding ten more civilizations, more leaders, more unique scenarios and late game buildings; it also adds natural disasters and expanded victory conditions, making the end game a lot more interesting. Civilization IV ‚Äì The Complete Edition is an amazing package, with virtually endless fours of fun that players want to spend time with, even if just for‚Ä¶ one‚Ä¶ more‚Ä¶ turn‚Ä¶

Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a timeless masterpiece that has captivated strategy gamers for over a decade. From its engaging gameplay mechanics to its intricate diplomacy system, Civilization IV is an experience that is as fun as it is intellectually stimulating.

At the heart of Civilization IV lies the core of its gameplay, which revolves around building a thriving civilization from scratch. Players begin as a small tribe with limited resources and gradually expand their reach across the map by developing new technologies, building infrastructure, and negotiating with other civilizations. The game offers a variety of paths to victory, including military conquest, cultural dominance, and scientific advancement, giving players the freedom to play the game in their own way.

One of the game's standout features is its diplomacy system, which allows players to forge alliances, trade resources, and negotiate peace treaties with other civilizations. The system is deep and nuanced, allowing players to use a variety of tactics to achieve their goals, from coercion and bribery to charm and flattery. The system also takes into account each civilization's unique characteristics, creating a dynamic and unpredictable playing field.

In addition to its gameplay, Civilization IV also boasts stunning visuals and a beautiful soundtrack that immerses players in the game's world. The attention to detail in the game's design is impressive, from the unique unit models to the lush environments and cityscapes.

Overall, Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a true masterpiece of the strategy genre. It combines engaging gameplay mechanics with an intricate diplomacy system and stunning visuals to create an experience that is both intellectually stimulating and immensely enjoyable. Whether you're a veteran of the series or a newcomer to the franchise, Civilization IV is a game that is not to be missed.

Two brief bits of clarification before I dig into the actual review:

1. My playtime is a lie. Beyond the fact that the DLCs act as standalone games, and your playtime on them doesn't contribute to the base game, I also owned the CD-ROM version back in the day, and played it until disc rot made it literally unplayable.

2. The base game isn't the definitive way to enjoy this game. Get the Beyond the Sword expansion, because you're honestly doing yourself a disservice if you don't.

Now, onto the review.

I am a historian. It's an integral part of me. It's what I've studied, it's what I explore in my free time, it's what I can talk about for hours without a pause. Civilisation 4 is a large part of the reason why. It came out when I was pretty young and I was always terrible at it, but for hours an hours on end, after I came home from school, I would play Civ 4. Hundreds of hours. Thousands of hours. I played this game for [b]years[/b] almost religiously. As mentioned above, the CD-ROM I played it on eventually succumbed to disc rot because of how much I was handling it.

Even without Civilisation's long and impressive pedigree, this is quite possibly the perfect historical 4x game. It's easy to jump into at low levels, but with layers upon layers of strategy to dig down into. The graphics are aged, sure, the sound design is rough around the edges, and even through my extremely rose-tinted glasses I can acknowledge that it has its jank and weird moments, but getting through that rewards you with an endlessly replayable experience, always fresh, always there, always ready for you to make your mark on the world. It [b]oozes[/b] charm and care. The technology quotes are narrated by the late Leonard Nimoy for Christ's sake! (One of his only non-Star Trek related video game credits alongside Kingdom Hearts, funnily enough.)

I still go back to it, year after year. Partially out of nostalgia, yes, but also because it hooks me like no other Civ game really can. Civ 5 is excellent, yes, and SM:AC probably some of the best science fiction ever put into video game format, but Civ 4 will always be my beloved.

And, if you've somehow extracted all the dopamine from the base game, fear not. The modding community for this game is prodigious, and it even comes bundled with a few of them to give you a taste. My personal recommendation, if you find the base game too slow or not detailed enough, is the truly ludicrous mod of Caveman2Cosmos.

Civilization IV is absolutely the best civ game and nobody will be able to convince me otherwise. I say this as someone who has played every civilization game except for Civ VI. I got the original game as a birthday present from my parents and became obsessed with each one since, so I know the strengths and weaknesses of them. The early civilization games were good, but had flaws. For instance, if you screwed up even a little bit, your game was finished. Never ending wars were a constant issue in civ 1-3 to the point where it became like Orwell's 1984; "we were always at war with Ghandi..." It was only truly fixed in this game where peace treaties became binding and it was not possible to cross borders without an open borders agreement (in the old games, you could keep troops in your opponent's territory and they would have to tell you to get out or declare war, after which most AI would declare war). So Civ 4 (this game) fixed these issues whilst still retaining the core gameplay which was utterly decimated in Civ V and newer versions. Later versions changed the core gameplay a lot and added complexity which doesn't really complement the game at all. Most people were happy that unit stacks were removed (i.e. you could no longer have 20 riflemen, 10 artillery, and 5 catapults on one tile) and with other changes to how combat works, but I feel that it ruined the game. It made combat more strategic in a way, but also more complicated in a bad way for gameplay & enjoyability. It's hard to describe exactly why, but Civ IV had the best of both worlds: the beginning of improvements that made civ better whilst also retaining the game mechanics and spirit of the old civ. 

Oh, and I actually have 300 hours on this game, plus a bit more from when I owned it before having a steam account. I don't know why, but it reset my hours when I reinstalled this game on my new PC.

Unlike most of the gamers I know, I never really cared for shoot'em'up or military conquest computer games. But games like solitaire and the ubiquitous merging games found on cell phones and computers today simply bore me to tears.  I have been playing Civilization from when the very first edition came out in 1991.  I welcomed CIV II and CIV III, but the advent of CIV VI gave me the strategy game I really was looking for.

I play CIV IV because it gives me the opportunity to win by diplomacy, cultural spread, and the space race as alternatives to outright war against the other civilizations. I play just the desktop mode, and generally customize to run the largest maps with marathon speed to let me really get into micromanaging the cities and units in games that might take me months to win, depending the real life time I have available to me.  

For me it is the journey  I take in developing my civilization, rather than the winning over the others that I enjoy.  I set the game to always be in a state of peace (which I know is unrealistic) and dive in to the complexities of diplomacy and culture to either work together with the AI's civilizations or to entice them to join me through my culture development (usually by culture bombing the border cities by having Great Artists move to those locations and creating their Great Works). 

I have yet to find another strategy game that caters as much to those players who don't enjoy warfare focused games as they do to those who are more interested in military conquest.  CIV IV lets both types of player have an enjoyably challenging time creating and growing their civilizations.

The Civilization series's marvellous! Perfect if you want to just chill, drink coffee, relax, and multi-task; since it's a turn-taking game. This is the one you want if your computer can't quite run Civilization 5 properly and it's the one you buy when Civilization 3 is just too primitive for you. Yes! This one's sure got a bundle of a bunch more spice than Civilization 3; however if you're looking for less of a challenge then turn back, right now. The A.I. still practically does almost everything it can do in it's power; once the planet-map's made; to completely work against you.. The only way I've discovered of keeping up to them and becoming somewhat of a super-power-nation, is to go with the flow; and hope to Jesus Christ that you've got some really great resources in the early game. (You want either a massive river or river-system/delta, you want one of your cities to be on the coast with fish, or/and any amount of stone/copper/iron/silver/gold/gems/diamonds in your close-reaching-grasp.) ((Big fertile lands of rivers with great farmland is just perfect for building up a large population to get things done or simply to raise a simple/large army/navy; although, you're definitely going to want at least one city in your empire to be on the ocean with some sort of type of fish... And don't forget to go nuts over things that either bring you much money: or things that'll upgrade the quality of your peoples' tools/weapons.)) A small army with an abundance of copper can easily annihilate a massive army of simple people who don't have access to creating bronze weapons out of a certain tin/copper consistency. I hope the game takes into account that hardened bronze takes at least 3 years to become hardened to almost it's maximum potential. It'd be even more silly if you had stone walls before the enemy tried breaking in with their soldiers, armed with bronze weapons: because if you researched archery and have some guys with bows/arrows in your walled-city - it can be crazy-difficult for the enemy to break into that. So, no... You really don't need copper and tin to become powerful, though, you need them to make bronze if you're going on the offensive. Which reminds me, if you choose to make your nation a slave-trade, which happens in the early game: after researching the ability to have bronze, you can become a slave-trade. I highly recommend that you do become a slave trade if you want to be successful at an incredible rate because it's simply one of the steps Mankind has to take in order to compete strongly with many other nations of men. (It's practically the only way to become a strong super power in the early game which usually means you actually have a shot at survival; I've done many games without doing the slave-trade thing and it always ends up with my nation getting left in the dust and fighting off against hoards of barbarians or simply getting erased by an enemy nation, who did decide to become a slave trade.) ((But to become a super successful slave trade, towering over all of your enemies, nearby: you absolutely need a source of copper connected with roads to your most military-enhanced city; which's usually got to either be your capital city or one that you created a barracks in, right off the bat.)) As far as becoming an extremely massive slave-trade, you really need to conduct assaults with the dudes who have bronze, 2-handed, axes.. Often just a few of these bronze-axe-men combatant armies can, easily and absolutely, wreck an enemy nation who isn't immersed with an amount of abundant copper. It's necessary to conquer these militaristically 'weaker' nations because: as a slave trade; you need to enslave many other people, you can't be enslaving many of your own people or there'll be turmoil in the streets and wonders of your own empire! As a slave trade, you must conquer at least one other nation; no matter how kind they are; or suffer radical and economic collapse. This is how you can become an economic powerhouse in the early times of the world or be prepared to be easily picked off a tree and eaten by; barbarians, your own people, or/and another slave-trading empire: it's practically like this anyway... To tell you the truth, complex strategy and being responsive in many ways are how you take off from being a slave trade. Choose a good religion for your people which suits the overall strategy of you and your empire. If you don't go a strong religious route and are not very successful in becoming a good and quite religious empire; then be prepared for your empire to go into revolution after revolution against you. I personally, always try to hit religion at the same time that Christianity is introduced in the game-match; it's also alright to take that religion from another nation: as long as you end up on top of them, at some point; power-wise. If your nation's the one that Christianity happens in via enabling a bit of liberty so it's much more possible - then you have the best ability to subdue the other nations, both with peace, obligations, or simply war. If your nation's the first Christian nation; you've really got the game in the bag and you really ought to save the game right then and there. I say this because the rest of the game's going to require much more, complex and responsive, immensely great strategy and tactics. Pick up as much iron as you can by this time; you need to prepare for the era of the future world wars: if they even erupt. You have to get ready to make complex machinery on an industrial level; definitely become a monarch along the way, too. You need oil deposits. If you don't have at least 2 deposits of iron connected with roads to your military production centres; and if you don't have at least one deposit of oil connected in the same way; you don't stand a chance in a world war. Become a thinker like an industrial revolutionary leader!!!!! If you don't have at least 2 units of infantry and at least one unit of some sort of combat-vehicle; like tanks, bomber-planes, or artillery: then go back to that save file that I told you to make, earlier. If you don't; then if a world war happens: and it's highly likely in this game: you're getting stomped and your nation will belong to another in a hurry. For the amount of raw, non-politically-correct, and difficult: realism: I give this game a 10/10. It really doesn't need the hottest graphics and sure lacks a bit in the quality of the sprites and what you get visually: this game isn't even for a wide screen monitor.. But, for what it's taught me about just how competitive you need to be as a people; in order to survive for thousands of years, even making choices that're considered major mistakes today: in order to maintain your people on a competitive level... I will not take off any of my rating for the lack of great visuals. (It's not the worst game on a graphic and visual level, but it could sure use a wide-screen version.) Civilization IV is a turn-based strategy game in which you attempt to rule a civilization from the dawn of civilization to the start of the real Space Age. You balance the development of your cities' infrastructure, the quantity and quality of your military, your research projects, and trade routes. And using whatever means you can, you vie for victory by achieving any of a variety of victory conditions, such as being the first to colonize space or by becoming the uncontested global superpower.

I played the balls absolutely off of Civilization II back in the Windows 98 days. It was an exceptional game for its time. But Civilization IV became my favorite entry into the late 2000s. The territory game mechanic in particular was a much appreciated improvement, in addition to graphical, UI, and music modernization efforts.

I only ever have two complaints with Civ IV, or with most of the Civilization games, One, that city management over long periods of time can be obnoxious to micromanage. It can be time consuming and aggravating to try and keep your cities keeping up with their infrastructure, and some of the later AI improvements to help automate this aren't always the best. Two, sometimes you get absolutely whacked by a large number of units that appear suddenly out of nowhere deep within your territory. I wish Civ IV had the mechanic included in even older Total War games to reduce this frustration, namely the ability for military units to construct watchtowers to maintain visibility (instead of requiring engineers to build forts).

In single playthroughs, these are not nearly enough to eliminate the fun of the game. But it does prevent playability without long breaks of time in between game installs.

Pros:
+ Nice graphics (for its time)
+ Nice UI (for its time) and map navigation
+ Large variety of Civs, Units, and city buildings
+ Hatshepsut is a cutie

Cons:
- Micromanaging can be exceptionally time consuming, which can make longer games boring, and hurts replayability
- You can't build watchtowers with military units to help with map visibility, guaranteeing that large stacks of enemy troops will somehow zip past your suburbs to whack you deep behind the actual front.

Rating: A- (for its time), B+ (for 2021)

Like other civilization games, civ IV has a built in civilopedia, and I recommend you use it, or the online version, whenever you discover a new social policy, building, or anything else that intrigues you. If you enjoy the process of learning a game, Civ IV is rich in mechanical complexity, perhaps even more so than its sequels, but you are by no means required to understand all of it on your first, or even your third, playthrough. Long ago, I had this game as a hard copy, and it was a major part of my childhood. I wound up getting this game again during the Summer Sale for nostalgia, and was pleasantly surprised to find it still held up 15 years (!) after release!


Music: Great quality, great selection, not to mention the Grammy-winning "Baba Yetu" as the main menu theme. 9/10.

Graphics: Dated, but very well detailed on max settings. Mods like Blue Marble exist that push things even further. 7/10.

Gameplay: Many consider this the best Civ game, including me. Civ IV gave this series its modern look and feel, and it is a formula that is still in use even with Civ VI, 15 years later. Where this loses its point is the lack of an interactive tutorial for new Civ players, but the Civilopedia is useful to help with this. 9/10.

Learning curve: Easy if you've played a Civ game before, hard to learn if you haven't. The Civilopedia has some info, but you'll need to figure some stuff out yourself. 7/10


Final Point Tally: 32/40 (Excellent)

Final Verdict: Buy this game. The expansions are not needed but will enhance the playthrough further, though they are not compatible with each other (to my knowledge). In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#333 out of 612)... it's time for Civilization IV.

It's a bit hard to talk about Civilization IV today. In many ways, Civilization IV is, you see, arguably the last genuinely great Civilization game. In many ways, its successor, Civilization V, is a superior game--more polished, more focused, with greater depth and better balance--and the definitive Civilization experience. But at the same time, I can't help but lament how unambitious subsequent Civilization games are--and that lack of ambition seems to be a patter currently affecting all of developer Firaxis' output. Rough around the edges though it may be, Civilization IV is still a fantastically engrossing and addictive turn-based grand strategy game, with hugely ambitious standalone expansions that radically transform the core rules and mechanics. Going back into Civilization IV today, one might be disappointed by the lack of modern polish--most especially the absence of tooltips and proliferation of awkward iconography in their stead--but despite it's self-evident age, I think Civilization IV still stands proud as a landmark 4x game.

And if Civilization IV on its own does not merit revisiting in the wake of Civilization V, its expansions--most notably Beyond the Sword--most certainly do.

I have bought this but mainly played Warlords, however it is basically the same thing.  As a huge fan of Civilization 3, I wanted to like this game so much.  The graphics are well done, and the camera does not allow rotation which I much prefer in any strategy game.

  Of course the first thing I noticed is the game is totally unbalanced.  The Africans get an attacking unit right at the start that can move 2 spaces and other civs cant move 2 spaces for like 200 more turns.  The "industrious" leaders all get a +50 or is it 100% bonus to great wonder building speed.  Why is that unbalanced?  Well because this game is 70% building great wonders there is a great wonder for almost every technology.  These types of things are  unacceptable in a strategy game really and I noticed they have all been fixed in Civ 6.  Well, what I did is I modified the XML files of this game.  It is surprisingly modifiable and that is a plus.  Of course you can't modify a lot of things and it is a hassle to figure out.

Okay lets talk about the audio.  You have Nimoy narrating which is fine with me, but when he tries to joke, awkward.  The sounds when managing cities, which you have to do alot, are annoying.  The music system is rediculous.  So what happens is it plays the "world theme" unless you zoom in, and then it plays your "civilization theme."  It gets louder and softer depending on your zoom level, and there is a spot in between where it plays no music basically.  This is also the spot where the graphics look the best but its still playable.  Now if you play it zoomed out like most you are going to find the "world theme" to be not very good, and when it changes to the modern age you will have some disturbing modern classical "doomed world" theme to listen to.

Speaking of doomed world, the game tries very hard to make it feel that way, closer you get to the end, you will be bombarded with GLOBAL WARMING destroying your cities I kid you not.  Also on the "Internet" wonder they have a picture of AL GORE and I think they paid him to be in the game and use his global warming MYTH that I guess he has a copyright on?

Now lets talk AI.  The AI is just as bad if not worse than Civ 3.  Barbarians appear out of nowhere anywhere there is fog of war, as do other civilizations that attack you.  I don't think other civilizations have to even research or produce units in their cities at all.  Their units just show up out of the fog of war after a certain amount of turns.  Modifying XML files probably does not even affect a computer controlled opponent.  When in war, they will have maybe one invasion force, if you defeat that or they cant land or regardless they are going to go around just destroying your fishing boats and fishing spots.  Most annoying thing ever and not fun.  The AI will never attack you, until about 1850 AD and if you are winning, and then of course they will always declare war on you.  The enemy moves don't animate properly most of the time, leading to enemy just magically appearing without the camera tracking them or even showing them at all.  Due to the way the game shows multiple units there can be a huge force under one weak unit and you cannot tell.

Other forms of victory like space race is way too difficult and then the game just ends with no reward but a short crappy cutscene of you staring at earth from a window.  Nukes are underpowered and unsatisfying.  If you play the game with "standard" size map get ready for your game to last 100+ hours.  The map size changes on the type you choose and its really hard to create the right size map.  There are in reality no random maps there are continents, pangea, or waterworld, and one called fractal which I have found just creates continents or pangea.  I like to play maps with both continents and smaller islands and this game will not generate a map like that.

I highly recommend Civilization Revolutions over this, a great game for xbox 360, not perfect but way way better.

I've played Civ IV, Civ V, and Civ VI, and this is the runaway winner for the best strategy game.

What I want from a game is frequently being given lots of not-obvious decisions that matter, where the right answer can be deduced through careful thought and thorough knowledge of the game.  I'm wanting a game where these choices matter far more than the dice.  What I don't particularly care about are the graphics, the story, or the "emersive experience" of feeling like I'm really talking to Cleopatra.

In Civ IV, one worker option is cottages, which are the short-term loss/long-term gain option.  Civ IV balances it well enough that thinking long term isn't necessarily the right choice; you have to assess the odds of a war within 10-50 turns and think about it.

Another home-run is the civics.  Many of the options are niche-strategies, but collectively, it's likely that you should eventually choose a niche.  For instance, one average, theocracy is bad.  But sometimes, a war is coming, and the free experience motivates building an army and crushing someone.  Even in games where I don't do this, the fact that I had this option looming over every single turn from turns 100-200 drives home how open ended the game is for players who want to explore the frontiers of just how high of a difficulty level can be beaten.

Also more so than Civ V and VI, I find myself taking different tech paths each time, which helps keep the game fresh and different each time.  In Civ V, I quickly felt like I had found the "right" strategy, and was now only testing to see how far it could take me.  In Civ IV, I've never felt like I've mastered it, or even close.

Civilization IV is a really fun game, based on a formula of expansion, growth, and conquest. However, it does have some flaws.

Graphics- The graphics on this game are, by all standards, nothing special, but a vast improvement over previous Civ titles. Besides, graphics in a strategy game aren't really the main focus.

Sound- The game has some great music tracks, which are era specific and usually appropriate. While the music does get a bit repetitive, I still haven't gotten tired of the opening title. Gameplay- This is where Civ4 really shines. The game is really infinitely replayable, with infinite possibilities and completely ludicrous historical combinations to try! The city building and expanding mechanic is very solid, however combat needs A LOT of work. Battles are simplistic and very unbalanced at best, relying almost completely on numbers and tech level rather than strategy or practicality. I for one, feel that stone age spearmen should never be able to defeat attack helicopters. In addition to this, some of the civics and the entire religion mechanic are completely pointless, which is a shame, considering they could have been put to very good use. Ultimately though, the game is still very good, and very addictive. I give it an 8.

Probably the most addictive game I've ever played. The gameplay is pretty self-explanatory: you get to control a build one of the myriad world civilizations, and you must defend it and defeat your opponent. There are different ways to defeat your enemy, but it must be done before the time limit elapses. This s a turn-based game, which means after you play your turn, the computer plays its turn, and so on. Lots of different resources are available, for example gold, fish, iron, copper, ivory, stone, and more. With the passage of time, your civilization progresses from stone age all the way to the modern age. 

One of the major drawbacks of this game is the amount of effort and time that one must spend on managing the myriad resources in your territory; for example, if you assign villagers to cut down a forest, you must constantly check whether they have finished cutting a particular patch of the forest. After they are done, you have to order them to cut another patch of forest, for they will not do it automatically. Also there are so many different technologies and warrior upgrades available that it is very difficult to keep track of the prerequisites for each. For example, if I want to upgrade my arrowmen to crossbowmen, I must meticulously research the technologies/warrior required to get it done in the right sequence.  While the AI in this game is incredible, the difficulty of the game is extremely frustrating. Personally, I could not go past the third level of difficulty because of the ENDLESS twists and turns. And as I have mentioned before, this game is INSANELY addictive. For this reason I think the cons of this game outweight its pros. I eventually stopped playing this game and probably won't resume.

Pros:
[list]
[*]Extreme modding flexibility. You can do some slight modification with XML, but man, you can do A LOT with python. The engine is so robust that you can play a fantasy world (Fall From Heaven 2), a civil war (RevolutionDCM), the neolithic age (Caveman2Cosmos) and so much more.
[*]Cities have their own identity. There's no bullcrap about some third world colony somehow making your citizens mad; not every war is Vietnam. Not to mention, culture is actually culture, foreign nationals will hate you and want to return to their country. This is further enhanced by RevolutionDCM.
[*]Your empire-building choices are diverse. There's no single answer to every choice you make; you have to design your cities to develop your country. You can move towards having industrial powerhouses, settle cities specifically for commerce and tax money, settle in far lands to establish cultural dominance, establish a corporate center, fill your coffers with the tithe of a holy city, feed your citizens specifically to enslave them, and so on and so forth. You have to work for your +50 gold, not click on some OP religious bonus.
[*]Your government is flexible. Communism and Fascism isn't fully fleshed out in the game probably for fear of poltical backlash, but all of the obsolete policies before modern government do have their merits. A caste system helps you with making sure you have a lot of merchants, slavery ensures you have fast production, mercantilism makes sure the benefits of trade isn't shared with your enemies.
[*]There is a war before war. Civ4 espionage and diplomacy is especially well-developed as there's no such thing as simple friend or enemy. Political blocs do exist, and there will be civs that support your power to ensure their safety, but they all have their intrigue to make sure you're not too powerful. Information war and proper war-planning exists in this game; if you don't have vision of your enemy's cities or units, you might end up with a severe counter of axemen destroying your swordsmen. Destroying your rival's economy can be done through espionage as well as poisoning the wells of their wonderful cities can hold them back, and yes, there is a chance for you to destroy a 1-turn progress towards building a wonder.
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
[*]You need to think. Civ4 isn't dumbed down for the wide market like Civ5 or Civ6.
[*]You will lose track of time.
[*]No Steam workshop. This is an old game.
[*]Old graphics, but with the right mods it can be repaired.
[*]Turn times may get very slow, especially with huge mods like Caveman2Cosmos.
[/list]
Overall, I would only recommend this to gamers who know strategy or history very well. In my opinion, I think playing without victory conditions can be very fun as role-playing countries can be a wonderful experience, and developing mods can be a joy as Civ4 becomes your alternative history simulator.

SIDENOTE: This was my first Civilization game. I played it back in 2009 for hundreds of hours (before I had Steam of course). It was one of the two games to get me to switch from console to PC gaming.

Nostalgia aside, this is definitely tied for the title of "Best Civilization Game" with Civilization 5. There's a lot to like and there's some stuff to dislike about it. First, the positives.

The game looks like a game that came out in 2005 but it's not a bad looking game by any means. What you see in the screenshots on the Steam page is what it looks like in game. I also think that the game has a much higher learning curve compared to the newer iterations of the Civilization franchise, or at the very least compared to 5, BE, and 6. There's a lot more micromanaging in this game than the newer games. 

Moving on to the negatives, the game does feel very dated, and that becomes appearent at some of the mechanics. The movement isn't as good, since in Civ 4 they were still using square tiles, which makes some combat and movement feel terrible at times. The newer games have hexagonical tiles instead, and they're vastly superior to the square tiles of earlier games. But more importantly, the UI isn't that great. It can be a bit confusing, especially to newer players. 

Finally, some of the mechanics are completely barebone. There's a lot of stuff here to have fun with, but some mechanics aren't fleshed out enough (like city health) and just means that you have one more thing to micromanage instead of it being a completely different thing to keep track of.

Overall though, I would still recommend it because while it is starting to show its age, it's good enough that you can overlook some of the minor flaws that the game has. Also, it has one of the best soundtracks in the history of games period. Definitely pick this one up if you're a fan of 4X turn-based strategy games.

I still recommend this as the best Civilization game ever made. Even though the series is two iterations out, the Civilization series made a terrible misstep that it has yet to rectify: 1 Unit Per Tile (or 1UPT for short)

Civilization takes place on a large strategic map, representing the entire world,  that's divided into tiles that each have their own features and terrain. War is waged by moving military units across these tiles.

The problem with 1UPT is a matter of perspective, and the matter of strategic vs. tactical combat. "Strategy" refers to the grand overall execution of a war by a nation's military, while "tactics" refers to the actions that a military unit takes in a single battle. A game series that's well-known for featuring both the strategic and tactical view of armies is Total War, and it shifts between the perspectives very well.

The problem is that Civilization does not shift between these perspectives (not that I really want it to, as I think that goes against the spirit of the game), so Civilization V and Civilization VI have tactical combat taking place on a map meant for strategic combat. In Civilization IV and all prior Civ games, you move your military units and when they meet an opposing force, RNG simulates what happens on a tactical level. It makes sense and it fits the strategic perspective of the playing field.

Civ5 and Civ6 use the same perspective, but the 1UPT restriction makes it so that on 1 tile, which represents a few hundred square miles, you have only one military unit. That doesn't make sense!

And I understand why there's a number of people who prefer it. They hate so-called "Stacks of Doom". In every Civ game through Civ4, you can have a theoretically infinite number of military units on one tile. These can quickly decimate a defending city's military if the stack of attacking units is large enough.

But that's the point!

If the enemy is able to defeat you with a stack of doom, then it's on you for not making your own stack to defend. Civilization isn't just about combat. It's also what happens between combat. It can also be about avoiding combat, if that's what you're going for. You need to build up the production of your cities, and then you need to produce wisely. Civilization is about more than managing a military, it's about managing your economy and infrastructure.

Forcing tactical combat on Civ puts too much weight on the military aspect of the game, since you have the headache of figuring out which military unit goes on which tile. And because Civ has ways to win the game peacefully, it goes against the spirit of the game to put that much weight on management of the military.

So, until Civilization reverses the horribly-flawed design choice of 1UPT, Civilization IV is still the prototypical Civilization game. It is the pinnacle of everything that Civilization is meant to be, and I hope that in time, Firaxis will understand the error of their ways and leave the 1UPT nonsense to games that are actually meant to be tactical combat games.

An Absolute Classic. Many great memories with this game. Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a cult classic, and for good reason. Fun, fast paced gameplay, extensive research trees, interesting tech that completely changes the landscape of the playing field. Being over a decade old, the visual aspect of the game is understandably lacking nowadays, but you see everything you need to. The extensive choice of rulers and perks that come with different civs is commendable. It provides the player with the feeling that they have much more control over the course of their civilization, and this gives a unique depth to the world. As is the standard with Sid Meier's video games, the player truly feels like they are discovering something never before seen when they trek the vast expanse of water in their Caravan for the first time. Multiplayer mechanic is a perfect platform for competitive players or cocky friends to challenge each other to a great, long run of civ and gives way to an incredible, unique experience that no other game can quite achieve. A truly unique game that spans across generations, and will surely be remembered for its incredible run as the go-to RTS game. I speak with a heavy dose of bias, and the game does suffer a bit from graphical glitches, bugs, the occasional crash, etc., but it's an experience everybody deserves to have at least once.

I'm a long-time fan of the Civ series (from the original "Civilisation" onward) and it was pretty inevitable I'd be getting around to this game eventually.  So, the main differences from Civ 3 I can see are these: it's got a lot more different types of resources; the tech tree has been tweaked and had a few more items added in; there are more Wonders and types of Wonder; there's the whole new "religions" stream of progress options (very Pokemon, in a way - collect them all!);  there's better animation of your units (and you can see your unit as a group, rather than a single individual); civic rules are a lot more customisable across a variety of dimensions (political, economic, social, religious); and you've lost the ability to tweak your palace or view your city close-up.  Oh, and the game can be customised to a much greater degree than before.

It still has a lot of the same basic assumptions (and thus a lot of the same basic pitfalls) as the earlier games in the series.  A victory via conquest or other aggressive means is always going to out-score a victory by cultural hegemony or other such peaceful means.  The view of "progress" is still very linear, and there's very much a perspective of "the only way is up" (now, admittedly, I haven't really got to the modern era all that often, so I don't know whether there's still the pollution and global warming hazards to be aware of - I really should read the manual to be sure).  The world leaders you're playing are very much biased toward European and Western cultures (there's China, Japan and India representing Asia; Mali and Egypt representing Africa; and the Incas representing South America; meanwhile there's the USA, England, Spain, France, Germany, Russia, Greece, Rome and Persia representing Europe and the global West), so the whole issue of over-emphasis on technologies found useful in the global "West" is a thing.  However, as I said, these are standard problems (of the "this thing I like is somewhat problematic" variety) with the entire series - it's very much a case of either they're deal-breakers for you  as a player, or you accept the game for what it is, and make a mental note of the problematic bits to think about later.

Gameplay-wise, it's much the same as all the other iterations of the series: you move any pieces you have available to move, and press enter to signal the end of your turn.  If you don't have any pieces to move, the game will sit there prompting you to press "enter" until the skies fall (my biggest gameplay annoyance, quite honestly), but then, this [i]is[/i] a turn-based game, and that's what you're in for as a result of playing it.  (Oh, and if you didn't already have every single turn-based game known to humanity sitting in your Steam preview queue before you started playing, you will shortly afterwards... or maybe that's just me).

I can't comment on the multi-player aspect of the game, because I don't play multi-player (I play games to relax, not to stress myself out by getting pounded into the dirt).  The music is very pleasant (and very repetitive) and you're able to turn it down or off as this suits you.  

Given I play this game to relax, and I'm not really into high scores or anything like that, I'm probably not the best person to review it.  But overall, I'm finding Civ 4 to be an interesting upgrade from Civ 3, and I'm really liking finding out how to handle all the new bits and pieces in the game.

(This refers to Civilization IV with Warlords and Beyond the Sword.   Also, ignore my playtime; I put 100s of hours into Civ IV BTS off a disk.   I got the Steam version for convenience sake.)

This is arguably the best 4x game ever made; I don't think I am alone in this opinion.   What make it so is a combination of things, not just individual features.   The variety of strategies, the diplomacy, the range of units possible, the difference in the character of the Civs, I don't know I could go on and on and I think there are people who can say it better.

There are two points I do want to make in passing, however.   First, Civ IV was an evolution of Civ 1, 2, and 3.   Some people criticize it because it is an evolution, not a revolutionary new take on 4x.    Personally, I think taking all the good stuff and making it better and adding little stuff that made the whole pie a beautiful thing to experience is a very, very good thing.    Second, Civ IV Vanilla was a very good game, but not a world beater.   The addition of Warlords and especially Beyond the Sword is what made it great.    Of course there are a  lot of mods out there if you want, but the fact is that the only mod I think you might want to get a great gaming experience is the Bug Mod, which doesn't change the game play at all but adds a lot of helpful tools.

In Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword I am preparing to conquer the world with my mighty Celtic army. Civilization IV is an awesome strategy game in which almost anything is possible. There are so many different leaders to choose, and many different ways to beat the game. Sure, you could do a military victory, but you can also win diplomatically, artistically, and financially. For those of you kind of wary of strategy titles, let me assure you this is a very newbie friendly game. There are a variety of difficulties, and very detailed tutorials to help out. Also, being turn based has a huge advantage in being able to think out what you want to do. Having played Paradox Interactive titles like Victoria II, this is a far cry from the level of complexity found in those games. Nor is it very concerned with historical authenticity. When I first played as Boudicca, a warrior queen of the Celts, I expected to run into one of the Caesars, but instead I ran into General Bismark! My husband demonstrated some interesting divergents from history by having his Germans found Judaism 8), Christianity, and Islam. By what should have been mid-early Dark Ages, his musketmen were busy conquering the Russian Civilization. By the Industrial Revolution, his assorted tanks were conquering the world. I have been playing Civ 4 for a while now, and I have to say that it's a great game to pass the time. It is also a good game to play if you want to end up ruling the world and are unsure of how to do it - um, did you just read that?

So anyway, first of all there's a bunch of empires all with their own technologies, pros, cons and so on. And for each empire you get at least one leader. Each empire comes with a unique unit which can alter gameplay, such as the English redcoat, the French musketeer or the German Panzer Tank.

That brings me to the next great part - the units in the game. You start off with one city, and from there you can choose to make/train anything you have the technologies and resources to make/train. For example, you can train a warrior to fight, a scout to explore the map, a settler to find a new city, and later in the game (literally almost at the end), if you have the right stuff, you can make nukes!

The real icing on the cake is the fact that it is all so - well, real. You make contact with a new country, you make peace with them, you trade with them, you give them stuff - and then they can turn on you. Honestly Germany, why did you? You beat me, and I had grenadiers, war elephants and artillery; all you had were a few archers and a single catapult!

And last but not least, there's the winning. You can win by lots of ways: getting the most points by 2050, getting to Alpha Centauri first (space victory), controlling at least half the world, killing all other civilizations etc. All this great stuff turns the game into a real life simulation that is addictive and super fun. 10/10
